columns.text: In this problem, we will solve for the annual depreciation of an equipment using the Modified Accelerated Cost Recovery System (MACRS) method.

Depreciation refers to how much value is lost on a certain asset each year throughout its lifespan. There are two ways to solve for the depreciation. The first is straight-line depreciation where the value lost is the same each year throughout the duration of the asset's lifespan.

The other way to solve for depreciation is by using the Modified Accelerated Cost Recovery System (MACRS). With this, it takes into consideration that a new asset will most likely have a lower depreciation value and as time passes, the depreciation value increases.

In the MACRS model, the rates are not the same all throughout the lifespan. For this particular item, the rates are given below:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Year 1}&=0.1429\\
\text{Year 2}&=0.2449\\
\text{Year 3}&=0.1749\\
\text{Year 4}&=0.1249\\
\text{Year 5}&=0.0893\\
\text{Year 6}&=0.0892\\
\text{Year 7}&=0.0893\\
\text{Year 8}&=0.0446\\
\end{aligned}$$

In order to solve for the depreciation value, we will multiply the initial cost to the given rate. We will then subtract the depreciation value from the initial cost to get the **end-of-the-year book value**.

The initial cost will then be multiplied to the rate at Year 2 then subtracted to get the end-of-the-year book value, and the process repeats until the end of the asset's lifespan.

Solving for the depreciation at **Year 1**, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$1,375,000 \times 0.1429\\[15 pt]
&=\$196,487.50
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation at Year 1 is $\$196,487.50$

Subtract the depreciation from the initial value to get the end-of-the-year book value at Year 1

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{End-of-the-year book value}&=\$1,375,000-\$196,487.50\\[15 pt]
&=\$1,178,512.50
\end{aligned}$$

The end-of-the-year book value at Year 1 is $\$1,178,512.50$

Multiply the initial cost to the to the depreciation rate at **Year 2**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$1,375,000 \times 0.2449\\[15 pt]
&=\$336,737.50
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation at Year 2 is $\$336,737.50$

Subtract the depreciation from the initial value to get the end-of-the-year book value at Year 2

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{End-of-the-year book value}&=\$1,178,512.50-\$336,737.50\\[15 pt]
&=\$841,775.00
\end{aligned}$$

The end-of-the-year book value at Year 2 is $\$841,775.00$

Multiply the initial cost to the to the depreciation rate at **Year 3**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$1,375,000 \times 0.1749\\[15 pt]
&=\$240,487.50
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation at Year 3 is $\$240,487.50$

Subtract the depreciation from the initial value to get the end-of-the-year book value at Year 3

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{End-of-the-year book value}&=\$841,775.00-\$240,487.50\\[15 pt]
&=\$601,287.50
\end{aligned}$$

The end-of-the-year book value at Year 3 is $\$601,287.50$

Multiply the initial cost to the to the depreciation rate at **Year 4**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$1,375,000 \times 0.1249\\[15 pt]
&=\$171,737.50
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation at Year 4 is $\$171,737.50$

Subtract the depreciation from the initial value to get the end-of-the-year book value at Year 4

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{End-of-the-year book value}&=\$601,287.50-\$171,737.50\\[15 pt]
&=\$429,550.00
\end{aligned}$$

The end-of-the-year book value at Year 4 is $\$429,550.00$

Multiply the initial cost to the to the depreciation rate at **Year 5**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$1,375,000 \times 0.0893\\[15 pt]
&=\$122,787.50
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation at Year 5 is $\$122,787.50$

Subtract the depreciation from the initial value to get the end-of-the-year book value at Year 5

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{End-of-the-year book value}&=\$429,550.00-\$122,787.50\\[15 pt]
&=\$306,762.50
\end{aligned}$$

The end-of-the-year book value at Year 5 is $\$306,762.50$

Multiply the initial cost to the to the depreciation rate at **Year 6**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$1,375,000 \times 0.0892\\[15 pt]
&=\$122,650
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation at Year 6 is $\$122,650$

Subtract the depreciation from the initial value to get the end-of-the-year book value at Year 6

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{End-of-the-year book value}&=\$306,762.50-\$122,650\\[15 pt]
&=\$184,112.50
\end{aligned}$$

The end-of-the-year book value at Year 6 is $\$585,164.90$

Multiply the initial cost to the depreciation rate at **Year 7**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$1,375,000 \times 0.0893\\[15 pt]
&=\$122,787.50
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation at Year 7 is $\$122,787.50$

Subtract the depreciation from the initial value to get the end-of-the-year book value at Year 7

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{End-of-the-year book value}&=\$184,112.50-\$122,787.50\\[15 pt]
&=\$61,325
\end{aligned}$$

The end-of-the-year book value at Year 7 is $\$61,325$

Multiply the initial cost to the depreciation rate at **Year 8**:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Depreciation}&=\$1,375,000 \times 0.0446\\[15 pt]
&=\$61,325
\end{aligned}$$

The depreciation at Year 8 is $\$61,325$

Subtract the depreciation from the initial value to get the end-of-the-year book value at Year 8

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{End-of-the-year book value}&=\$61,325-\$61,325\\[15 pt]
&=\$0
\end{aligned}$$

The end-of-the-year book value at Year 8 is $\$0$
As we can see, at the end of the asset's lifespan, its value is zero which means that the solution is correct.
